pros:
Diverse work place with many opportunities to work on many different types of systems and learn a tremendous amount of science. Friendly, helpful, and intelligent people to work with and around for the most part. 

New Mexico Tech is across the street and a good education for the price.
cons:
The pay was very low for the amount of skills needed and acquired by NRAO employees. 
Decline in benefits during the decade of my employment was large as the benefits were a main attraction to becoming employed with this organization. 

Located in Socorro, NM which is small and limited in businesses and entertainment.

pros: Normally, it's a low stress friendly place to work. Vacation and retirement plans are very good. Work-life balance and flexibility for taking time off are very good.  If the budget ever improves, I'll give 5 stars.
cons:
The observatory budget has been an overarching negative issue for the past several years. A couple of years ago, this resulted in letting several people go. Last year it resulted in a change (much for the worse) of medical insurance. We were also furloughed for two weeks during the federal government shutdown. In the past 3 years, there has been a single salary increase of 2%. The director is ever hopeful that the budget situation will improve, but that might be as much for show to mitigate morale decreases than anything else. 

Some people, mainly on science staff, need to go through a Manners 101 class to learn how to interact and play nicely with others. Fortunately, that's a minority of employees.

pros:
The people are interesting and congenial (with notable exceptions) and the organization is entirely devoted to advancing basic science rather than selling ads, making weapons, etc., and generally enriching the already over-rich.  

The work/life balance can be quite good and there are 24 days of vacation (for professional employees) and 10 holidays; sick leave accrues at 12 days per year.  

Since the main facilities are located in small towns, the commute can be negligible.  Once adapted to, the small town pace can make city-dwelling problematic ;-)
cons:
Significant organizational problems leading to the lack of teamwork; key work often relies on tenured scientists who are entirely unmanageable and frequently uncivil (and since being the squeaky wheel works well here, why not).  Non-scientists, even in professional fields, are decidedly second class employees.  Pay is below average and the medical benefits get markedly worse every year.  Salary adjustments are rare and small; promotion is even rarer.  Professional development resources are spotty at best. Computer hardware is mediocre at best.  Software projects typically and unapologetically use the cowboy development process.  

With federal support for science  not keeping up with inflation things related to money are unlikely to get better.  

As with many organizations where software isn't the main product, software is considered a necessary evil and there are too many people who think they know software but don't---a little knowledge is truly a dangerous thing.

In NM, the town is probably too small and many services require driving 90 minutes to Albuquerque.  Educational and enrichment opportunities for children are definitely lacking which has led people to leave or locate in Albuquerque (a long commute).  The lack of job opportunities for spouses has also led people to locate in Albuquerque.  There's a hospital in town but even something simple can require driving to Albuquerque for follow-up care.

pros: NRAO is an institute that operates world's leading radio astronomical telescopes. It cannot be achieved unless all people in different professions, e.g., engineers, scientists, and office workers. I feel comfortable working at NRAO because of the respectful atmosphere to colleagues.
